article.description:
No. 17 Louisiana Tech had too much
quickness and too many scorers for New Mexico.
article.headline: Louisiana Tech hits 15 of 31 shots in second half
article.linkText: Louisiana Tech too quick, too good for New Mexico
article.story:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. -- No. 17 Louisiana Tech had too much
quickness and too many scorers for New Mexico.

Trina Frierson scored 17 points and Cheryl Ford grabbed 18
rebounds Saturday to lead the Lady Techsters to a 67-54 win over
New Mexico.

	   "We did a good job in the second half of milking the clock,
taking good shots and holding them to one shot," Louisiana Tech
coach Kurt Budke said after the win.

	   The Lady Techsters trailed 36-33 with a minute gone in the
second half, then used a 13-1 run over the next five minutes to
take a 46-37 lead.

	   New Mexico (8-3) got no closer than eight points the rest of the
way.

	   Jordan Adams led New Mexico with 19 points, while Chelsea Grear
scored 16 points and had 10 rebounds. The 6-foot-3 Adams hit 9 of
26 shots while working against the Lady Techsters' bigger
frontline.

	   Louisiana Tech (7-2) took control of the game in the second half
by repeatedly going inside on offense to the 6-foot-2 Frierson, the
6-3 Ford and 6-4 Amisha Carter.

	   Ford added 13 points and Carter 10 as the Lady Techsters
frequently scored off offensive rebounds and lobs into their
frontline trio.

	   "Time after time when we needed a stop, they got the O
(offensive) boards and put it back in,'"New Mexico coach Don
Flanagan said. "The physicalness of their play hurt us and their
quickness took some our confidence and skill away."

	   Frierson and Ford each scored 5 points and Carter added an
offensive rebound basket in the 13-1 run that put the Lady
Techsters in control. The spurt put the Lobos on their heels and
silenced the partisan New Mexico crowd of 9,692.

	   "There's very few places in America you have to prepare to take
the crowd out of the game," Budke said. "This is an unbelievable
atmosphere."

	   Louisiana Tech's quickness on defense caused New Mexico to force
shots in the second half, with the Lobos hitting just 9 of 35 shots
(26 percent).

	   Grear and Adams scored 26 of New Mexico's 33 first half points.
Grear, who hit 5 of 6 shots in the first half for 14 points, scored
her only basket of the second half on a steal and layup with 14:07
left. Adams and Grear hit 15 of 25 shots, but the rest of the Lobos
were 7-for-37.

	   Adams played 37 minutes and Flanagan said he probably should
have rested her more in the second half.

	   "I had to use Jordan because she was our only offensive
option," Flanagan said.

	   Adams scored in double figures for the sixth straight game, but
she and Grear needed more help from their teammates.

	   "You're not going to stop Jordan Adams," Budke said. "We
tried to stop everyone else."

	   Louisiana Tech hit 15 of 31 shots in the second half.

	   "We thought with our offense in front of our bench in the
second half, we could do a little better job of controlling the
game," Budke said.

	   New Mexico has played three ranked teams in the last teams this
month and went 1-2. They beat Texas and lost to Arizona.
